dialogue.message: An orphan is typically a child who has lost both parents, though some organizations consider a child who has lost just one parent as an orphan too.

dialogue.message: It must be hard being an orphan. I've known 2 orphans in my life who grew up in foster care

dialogue.message: Being an orphan can indeed be challenging, especially in foster care, though various organizations define orphanhood differently, even including those who've lost just one parent.

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: Some organizations, like UNICEF, consider a child who has lost just one parent an orphan, using terms like "maternal orphan" or "paternal orphan" based on which parent has passed away.

dialogue.message: but they weren't abandoned or orphaned through unforseen circumstances...how can they still be defined an orphan of any kind if they still have parents?

dialogue.speaker: Bot
dialogue.message: While common usage of "orphan" typically refers to a child who has lost both parents, organizations like UNICEF use the term to describe any child who has lost one parent as well, calling them "maternal" or "paternal" orphans.

dialogue.message: I get that but it still sounds silly. I think I may have to ask others who have had single parents raising them when they were children if they considered themselves an orphan

dialogue.message: Some organizations, like UNICEF, use broader definitions of "orphan" to include children who've lost one parent, which might seem unusual compared to the common understanding.

dialogue.message: While common usage only considers those who've lost both parents as orphans, organizations like UNICEF use the term for any child who has lost one parent, calling them "maternal" or "paternal" orphans.
